author: not_x912

author: timbeiko
content: I'm not aware of an extensive post, but in general the biggest argument against deflationary currencies is that it leads to hoarding over spending.

author: timbeiko
content: I think ETH has a few mechanisms to dampen the downsides.

author: timbeiko
content: First, the gas price market isn't fully ETH-denominated (e.g. 10 gwei at 100$ == 1 gwei at 1000$)

author: timbeiko
content: Second, ETH is pretty easy to use as collateral for other unit of accounts (e.g. open a loan on maker/aave/etc. and spend DAI vs. ETH)

author: timbeiko
content: I think the big question is whether it would affect ETH-denominated markets, and the interactions there seem like the hardest to untangle.

author: timbeiko
content: The first obvious one is staking, which requires 32 ETH. Hopefully we can keep working on lowering that threshold to keep it accessible.

author: timbeiko
content: The second is anything that usually is priced in ETH, e.g. NFTs. I'm really not sure  how increasing the deflationary aspect of ETH affects this, esp. given there is such a "speculation premium" to most of these markets, and whether ETH is deflationary or not may make a negligible difference.

author: timbeiko
content: Would love to see such an analysis in more detail, though!
